4.60.text: These people are amongst the greatest quiz players in Britain.

10.04.text: Together, they make up the Eggheads,

11.84.text: arguably the most formidable quiz team in the country.

17.32.text: The question is, can they be beaten?

24.92.text: the show where a team of five quiz Challengers

27.28.text: pit their wits against possibly the greatest quiz team in Britain -

32.64.text: Hoping to beat the might of the Eggheads today

36.56.text: Now, as you may have guessed,

37.96.text: this team all share a passion for knitting

40.56.text: and regularly swap yarns - see what I did there? -

43.92.text: at the same knitting group in Glasgow.

47.56.text: Hello, I'm Audrey, and I'm a retired teaching auxiliary.

50.96.text: Hello, my name's Andrea, and I'm a primary school teacher.

54.12.text: Hello, I'm Ellen, and I'm a retired primary school teacher.

59.08.text: and I'm a retired police community support officer.

62.20.text: Hi, I'm Peta, and I'm a field archaeologist.

65.40.text:
- So, Audrey, team, welcome. Good to see you here. 
- Thank you.

68.64.text: Tell us about the Knotty Knitters.

70.16.text: Well, the Knotty Knitters are the Glasgow Knit 'n Stitch,

73.64.text: and we're a group of knitters of various ages and abilities,

79.32.text: We've been going for ten years.

80.92.text: We don't all meet at the same time, but we meet

83.76.text: and we have a jolly good time as well.

85.40.text: We knit, we stitch, we drink coffee, we eat cake,

88.60.text: and we put the world to rights.

90.40.text: So, and do you all knit the same kind of things?

92.36.text: You knit scarves and jumpers, or what?

94.00.text:
- Mainly we're all knitting socks and scarves. 
- LAUGHING: Yeah.

97.36.text: And we think of grannies, click, click, click, knitting,

99.92.text:
- but it's not, is it? 
- No. 
- It's all ages now. 
- No.

102.32.text: All ages, and we have a chap that comes to the knitting as well.

106.56.text: And we have older people, younger people -

109.24.text: we've even had children at some point.

111.20.text: They would even be welcome, this lot over here, would they?

114.80.text:
- Yeah. Teach them a stitch or two. 
- THEY LAUGH

116.84.text: Well, good luck in the quiz against the Eggheads here.

119.24.text: Every day there is £1,000 worth of cash

121.16.text: up for grabs for our Challengers.

122.76.text: However, if they fail to defeat the Eggheads,

125.16.text: the price money rolls over to the next show.

127.48.text: So, Knotty Knitters, the Eggheads have won the last 12 games,

132.84.text: and that is handy for you,

134.12.text: because it means £13,000 is on the table for you to win.

138.32.text:
- So, do you want to crack on? 
- Yes.

140.40.text:
- Knit one, purl one, is it? 
- Mm-hm.

142.52.text: OK, maybe we can purl five.

144.36.text: The first head-to-head battle is on the subject of Science.

149.52.text: Who's going to go for Science? Are you heading for Science?

152.20.text:
- That was you, wasn't it? 
- Yeah? 
- Beverly?

154.60.text:
- Might as well give it a try. 
- Don't go yet, Beverly.

157.04.text: Beverly, tell us which Egghead you'd like to take on.

160.04.text: I think I'll take on CJ, please.

162.68.text: Right, so Beverly from Knotty Knitters

164.88.text: versus the man whose a complete knotty...

174.80.text: Please go to our Question Room now.

181.00.text:
- How are you feeling? 
- Fine, thank you. 
- Good.

186.64.text: OK. So, it's Science, and would you like to go first or second?

195.08.text: CJ, first question to you, then.

197.56.text: In 2014, scientific research debunked the myth

201.00.text: that which birds are attracted to shiny objects?

208.64.text: Well, this part of important research must have passed me by,

212.64.text: but traditionally magpies are attracted to shiny things,

215.76.text: so I will assume it's magpies.

217.84.text: Magpies is the right answer. Well done.

220.36.text: Beverly, your question. Which sport did

222.72.text: Alan Shepard play when he landed on the moon in 1971?

230.00.text: Well, it's unlikely he would've played tennis

232.80.text: since he would've needed a partner.

234.84.text: He wouldn't have had the facilities, I imagine, to play snooker,

240.52.text: HE CHUCKLES Great process of elimination there.

243.36.text: You're quite right. Yeah, the snooker table,

245.68.text: I don't know how that would've worked, really.

247.96.text: Sports you can't play on the moon. Number three.

252.04.text: Entomophobia is a fear of what?

259.36.text: Just to be sure, could you just spell the root of that?

265.84.text: Well, ento- is the usual word relating to insects,

272.12.text: so you've got entomology, which is the study of insects,

274.56.text: so I will assume it's insects.

276.36.text: Insects is quite right. Two to you.

278.56.text: Back to you, Beverly, to catch up.

280.48.text: What was the approximate length of a Tyrannosaurus rex

282.96.text: from its nose to the tip of its tail?

291.80.text: Well, I imagine it was much bigger than six metres.

296.08.text: I think there's one in the Natural History Museum,

303.24.text: Very big. CJ, is she right, do you think?

305.04.text: I certainly wouldn't have gone for that one.

306.96.text: I'm not sure between the other two, but 18 metres seems far too big.

309.80.text: Yeah, 18's too big. Six is too small, as you said, Beverly.

312.44.text: It's the middle one, actually - it's 12.

314.32.text: Now, because you allowed CJ to go first, he has the initiative.

317.68.text: If you get this right, CJ, you're in the final round.

320.24.text: The fuel in the solid rocket boosters

322.68.text: that powered NASA's Space Shuttle into orbit

326.00.text: is a powdered form of which element?

334.40.text: There's one of those there that's immediately jumping out at me,

337.16.text: but whether it's right or not, I don't know.

339.20.text: I certainly don't think it's sulphur.

341.56.text: I mean, the one that immediately jumped out at me was potassium,

350.08.text: ..erm, seems quite flammable when you set alight to it -

358.04.text: I mean, aluminium surely would be too expensive, anyway,

361.60.text: and maybe even too heavy, even in powdered form.

365.44.text: Really don't know this, but I'm going to go for potassium.

371.48.text: Or aluminum, as the Americans say.

373.60.text: So, a chance to get things equal here, Beverly.

378.60.text: Got to get this right to stay in.

383.36.text: is credited with pioneering which mode of transport

392.80.text: I'm pretty sure it wasn't a motorboat or an aeroplane.

397.80.text: Something in the back of my memory makes me think it was a bicycle.

407.44.text: Clawed your way back, Beverly - that's good.

411.04.text: Get's a bit harder, as you know, CJ -

414.44.text: Which scientist, a pioneer of antiseptic surgery,

417.56.text: was president of the Royal Society from 1895 to 1900?

423.84.text: Do I know anybody apart from Edward Jenner?

429.72.text: No is the simple answer. Edward Jenner.

436.40.text: the symbol for which unit of length

438.80.text: is a capital A with a little circle over it?

443.32.text: Never seen that symbol for acre, which is what springs to mind.

448.04.text: Can't think of anything that begins with A.

455.64.text:
- Is that a pass? 
- Got to pass on that.

462.28.text: CJ, your question. What is the usual name

464.52.text: for a substance used in vaccinations

467.96.text: that is capable of causing the production of an antibody?

476.92.text: Beverly, your question. A dilute solution of

486.20.text: is better known by what name?

488.80.text: And if you get this, you're in the final round.

493.92.text: Vinegar is the right answer. Well done.

495.84.text:
- You're in the final round. 
- Phew!

500.76.text: So, well done, Beverly - you're in the final.

502.68.text: Please come back to us, both of you, and we'll play on.

506.44.text:
- Famous victory there, Beverly. Well done. 
- Thank you.

508.80.text: You've got the Knotty Knitters off to an un-knotty start.

512.64.text: Fantastic. The knitting needles are flashing.

515.44.text: So, you've not lost a brain.

517.40.text: The Eggheads have lost one - the unmentionable.

521.88.text:
- Oh... 
- Oh, I see you wincing.

524.00.text: THEY GIGGLE Who would like this?

527.60.text: If it was Sport, it was going to... Or you were going to take it.

530.32.text:
- Or me. What do you want? 
- I don't know.

532.04.text:
- Go on, take it. 
- I don't mind. OK, I'll go for Sport.

534.40.text:
- I'll do Sport. 
- Andrea? OK, against which Egghead, Andrea?

537.48.text:
- Which Egghead am I going against? 
- I don't know about Lisa.

541.44.text:
- I don't know if she's any good at Sport. 
- I don't know. 
- Because...

544.24.text:
- I'll choose her anyway. Lisa, please. 
- OK.

546.64.text: So, it's going to be Andrea from Knotty Knitters

551.08.text: And if you would like to go to our Question Room, we'll crack on.

555.92.text: So, Andrea, I gather you're a huge Elvis fan.

558.08.text: Yes, I am. Very much so. Since I was about nine or ten.

561.32.text: I was just going to say we're about the same age,

563.40.text: so where did that come from?

564.64.text: Because it's a little bit before our time.

566.88.text: I watched GI Blues, I think it was, when I was nine,

569.76.text: and I thought, "Mm, I like his singing, I like the look of him."

572.44.text: So, my friend gave me a record token,

574.52.text: and that was my very first LP that I ever bought

578.04.text: Oh, and you must have been heartbroken when he died so young.

580.80.text: I was indeed. My plan was to go and see him in concert in Las Vegas,

585.56.text: And I gather you have made do with knitting an Elvis?

589.24.text: I have, yes. I've knitted an Elvis.

591.48.text: But I did... For my 50th birthday,

594.12.text: my partner, James, took me to see the virtual Elvis concert.

598.08.text:
- Oh, OK. Where he appears on the screen? 
- Yeah. 
- Yeah.

600.56.text: Or is he actually a hologram?

603.20.text: with his original backing group and singers and things.

607.88.text: So Sport, Andrea, is the round,

609.96.text: and would you like to go first or second?

616.52.text: Here we go with your first question.

618.40.text: In rugby union, how many points are awarded for a penalty?

625.12.text: I'm not really very sure, cos I don't watch rugby,

628.56.text: although I should cos my nephews played it.

631.00.text: I think, for a penalty, I'm going to go for three.

634.48.text:
- Three is right. 
- Oh! 
- Well done. 
- Thank you.

639.32.text: Which country won the 2014 Men's Football World Cup?

647.12.text: Do you know, my brain's just gone into meltdown,

649.56.text: and that's just absolutely the sort of thing

657.72.text: It is Germany. Yeah, you're quite right. Well done.

662.40.text: Which 21-year-old golfer won his second major of the year

673.40.text: Erm, well, sadly for Dustin, I've never heard of him,

676.16.text: so could very well be him, but I don't know.

678.56.text: And I've heard of Rory McIlroy, who was injured,

680.72.text: so I'm not sure if that was for the US,

683.16.text: but I have a feeling it might've been Jordan Spieth.

686.00.text: You're right. Golfing prodigy Jordan Spieth.

688.24.text: Well done. Two out of two for you.

690.44.text: Lisa, over to you. Which Englishman

692.52.text: won silver medals in the 400m and the 4X400m relay

704.96.text: I think he used to run the last leg

706.48.text: because he was the Olympic silver medallist.

708.56.text: Certainly, Akabusi and Regis were in that big '90s team,

712.56.text: but I think the only individual medallist in the 400 there

718.40.text: OK, Andrea, in 2012, which veteran rider

722.68.text: as part of the British show-jumping team on his horse Big Star?

731.72.text: Again, I don't know anything about this at all.

733.96.text: I do think David Broome is quite a long time ago,

736.92.text: so I don't know if it would be him.

740.36.text: And I've heard of Nick Skelton.

743.00.text: I've not heard of John Whitaker, so I'll say Nick Skelton.

749.16.text: I love your guessing - it's just fantastic...

751.24.text:
- I mean, no disrespect, I mean... 
- It is just guessing.

758.76.text: or whatever your favourite sporting analogy is.

762.08.text: Mike Hailwood was a leading name in which sport in the 1960s?

775.64.text: Can you spell Hailwood for me, please, Jeremy?

780.40.text: OK, that makes it slightly easier, I think.

786.28.text: Now, my first connection was with Mike Hailwood, with motorsport,

789.84.text: but now I'm wondering if I've mixed him up with Mike Hawthorn.

794.52.text: Is it snooker? Is it snooker? Is it snooker?

803.20.text: So, we've got quite a bit of Sudden Death going on here.

805.64.text: LISA SIGHS Equal after three questions.

810.32.text: I don't give you alternatives, a bit harder.

814.44.text: The footballer Diego Costa joined which Premier League team in 2014?

825.44.text: I'm not even sure I know of very many Premier League football teams.

840.88.text: OK, Lisa, Sudden Death. Andrea's got one wrong.

843.96.text: If you get this right, you're in the final round, and here it is.

846.96.text: For what does the letter H stand in the name of

849.40.text: the major North American professional sports league

857.28.text: which is your American approximation of football,

861.00.text: you've got your NBA, which is your basketball,

863.80.text: and you've got your NHL, which I think is hockey.

868.48.text: It's the National Hockey League - you're quite right.

870.84.text: You've taken the round, Lisa. Well done.

874.24.text: Please, both of you, come back to us.

875.80.text: Rejoin your teams and we'll play on.

880.36.text: Knotty Knitters have lost a brain from the final round,

883.00.text: the Eggheads have lost a brain as well.

884.64.text: We're evenly poised here, and the knitting is speeding up.

889.04.text: So, which knotty knicker, knitter would this?

891.08.text: THEY CHUCKLE Knotty KNITTER would like this?

893.52.text:
- Peta, you're good at geography. 
- That's you, my dear.

895.76.text:
- Yeah, OK. 
- It has to be you.

897.20.text:
- So, Knotty Knitter, Peta... 
- Yeah. 
- ..against which Egg?

902.72.text: So, Peta from Knotty Knitters versus Pat from the Eggheads.

905.32.text: To ensure there's no conferring, please go to our Question Room.

909.68.text: So, Peta, you are well-travelled, I know.

912.16.text: I've been to one or two places, yeah.

918.00.text: I don't think that's come up before as a destination.

922.08.text: It was a youth development expedition back when I was 18.

926.28.text:
- And you're an archaeologist now? 
- I am now, yeah.

928.40.text: Well, good luck in this round.

929.80.text: Digging for victory against Pat on Geography.

932.56.text:
- Do you want to go first and second? 
- I think I'll go second.

940.32.text: The Japanese flag features a red circle

943.08.text: on a background of what colour?

947.24.text: It's a red circle on a white background.

953.92.text: The Mexican peso consists of 100 what?

961.92.text: I'm trying to remember what the currency was when I was in Peru,

965.24.text: but I think that's completely different.

971.44.text: Centavos is quite right. Well done.

975.56.text: The Wash is an inlet of the North Sea

978.20.text: located between Norfolk and which other county?

988.76.text: Essex is to the south even further,

995.20.text: So, two points to the Eggheads, one to you, Peta.

1000.40.text: The names of how many US states begin with a vowel?

1012.52.text: I'll go down the middle. Ten.

1014.84.text: Peta, sorry. I've got 12 down here. I'm afraid you're wrong.

1018.20.text: OK, Pat, your question, for the round.

1020.40.text: Which is the only Central American country

1031.16.text: If you've got this right, you've taken the round.

1035.52.text: El Salvador is. Well done, Pat - you're in the final.

1037.92.text: Sorry, Peta. You got knocked out there.

1039.88.text: That's the way it goes sometimes.

1042.76.text: But don't worry - your team can still win.

1044.60.text: Come back to us, and we'll play the next round.

1048.64.text: So, Knotty Knitters have lost two brains from the final round now.

1052.52.text: The Eggheads have still just lost the one.

1054.96.text: Last round before the final is Music.

1057.44.text:
- Who would like this? 
- Ooh. 
- I'll take Music.

1062.24.text: And you can have either Dave or Kevin.

1066.60.text: OK, all right. He'll enjoy that.

1068.92.text: So, it's Audrey from Knotty Knitters

1070.76.text: against Kevin, our Egghead, on Music.

1073.64.text: Please go to our Question Room.

1076.84.text: OK, Audrey, if you get this round, you will have levelled it up.

1080.28.text:
- How are you feeling? 
- Er, fine, fine. 
- JEREMY LAUGHS

1083.16.text:
- Is music your thing? 
- Yes, yes. 
- OK. OK.

1086.52.text:
- Would you like to go first or second? 
- I'll go first, please.

1094.28.text: During which awards show did Madonna fall off the stage mid-performance

1108.12.text: Oh, when you watch them, they all seem quite similar, don't they?

1111.88.text: Erm... I'll disregard the Grammy Awards. Erm...

1116.72.text: I think I'll go for the Brit Awards.

1119.92.text: Yeah, you're absolutely right. Well done.

1121.88.text: It was the Brits, the Brit Awards.

1123.36.text: Kevin, your question. In which section

1139.36.text: Which song by The Jam includes the lines

1142.12.text: "Getting a cab and travelling on buses

1152.36.text: Ooh... Oh, I was never a Jam fan.

1157.56.text: I think I'll go for Town Called Malice.

1162.08.text: Although there is a bit of malice in there, you're right.

1164.52.text: In fact, there's a quite a lot of malice in all their songs.

1166.96.text:
- Yes, there was at the time. 
- Kevin, your question.

1169.32.text: Bon Scott was the lead singer of which rock group

1179.60.text: Yes, he was one of those front men who met with an unfortunate demise.

1186.00.text: It was AC/DC. Yeah, very sad.

1187.76.text: It was a whole sort of Spinal Tap thing, wasn't it, of...

1190.12.text:
- Well, yeah, I think was alcoholic poisoning in his case. 
- Yeah.

1194.60.text: Audrey, we've got the energy here.

1197.28.text: Let's just get this one right, stay in and topple him

1203.84.text: Chandelier was a hit single in 2014

1215.12.text: Ooh. Now, I've heard of Delta Goodrem and I've heard of Sia,

1218.88.text: but I've never heard of Iggy Azalea.

1221.56.text: Sia's the girl that has her face covered, isn't she?

1231.56.text: You're bang on, actually, Audrey. Well done.

1233.60.text: And it's great song as well. Sia, it is.

1236.20.text: So, you've got two out of three.

1238.04.text: We need to hope now that Kevin misses this one up.

1240.36.text: Which Tchaikovsky ballet features the Waltz of the Snowflakes?

1250.12.text: Er, I don't remember the Waltz of the Snowflakes, but...

1253.52.text: there's no good reason why that should be in Romeo and Juliet.

1256.88.text: In fact, he didn't do a ballet called Romeo and Juliet -

1259.60.text: he did a... I think he did an overture.

1263.16.text: So...I can't see any reason why it would be in Swan Lake,

1266.76.text: where as The Nutcracker does have lots of different...

1269.24.text: There's a whole suite of different little dances

1273.40.text: by a whole variety of animate and inanimate objects,

1279.24.text: And it's Christmassy as well, I guess, yeah.

1281.48.text: The Nutcracker is the right answer. The Waltz of the Snowflakes.

1284.80.text: Kevin, you've taken the round on Music. Sorry, Audrey.

1287.16.text: You ran him very close there...

1288.68.text: But the skipper's been knocked out.

1290.60.text: And if you come back to us, we will play the final round.

1295.96.text: So, this is what we have been playing towards -

1297.96.text: it is time for the final round,

1299.80.text: which, as always, is General Knowledge.

1301.76.text: But I'm afraid those of you who lost your head-to-heads

1304.20.text: won't be allowed to take part in this round.

1306.20.text: So Audrey, Andrea and Peta from Knotty Knitters

1311.16.text: would you please now leave the studio?

1316.60.text: you are playing to win the Knotty Knitters £13,000.

1322.04.text: that money can't really buy, which is your reputation.

1324.48.text: As usual, I will ask each team three questions in turn.

1327.64.text: This time the questions are all general knowledge.

1331.72.text: So, Knotty Knitters, the question is are your two brains able to...

1339.92.text:
- Stitch up. 
- ..to stitch up the four over here?

1342.80.text: There we are. We've got it.

1344.08.text: Ellen, would you like to go first or second?

1345.92.text: I think we've decided that we'll go first, thank you, Jeremy.

1351.56.text: So, all the very best to you. Playing for £13,000. Here we go.

1354.88.text: Who plays Max in the 2015 film Mad Max - Fury Road?

1364.36.text:
- I don't know. 
- I have no earthly idea.

1367.48.text:
- Do you anything about the film? 
- No. 
- Let me repeat the question.

1370.88.text: Who plays Max in the 2015 film Mad Max - Fury Road?

1380.96.text: Shall we just guess, and guess Andrew Garfield?

1385.56.text: So, it's going to be an absolute guess -

1389.76.text: and we're going to go for Andrew Garfield.

1392.52.text: Let's find out from the Eggs. Are they right?

1397.00.text: Remake of the famous one with Mel...

1403.52.text: Felipe VI became king of which country in 2014?

1410.28.text: Spain, isn't it? Are we all happy with Spain?

1412.32.text:
- After JC did one. 
- Yeah, Spain, yeah.

1415.12.text: We're going to go for Spain, please, Jeremy.

1418.52.text: Dave, the correct answer is Spain. Well done.

1425.00.text: by our fingernails or whatever we need to use.

1427.72.text: Who became the host of the US chat show

1438.80.text: I think... I had a feeling...it was James Corden.

1443.96.text: There's something recently that Piers Morgan has been in.

1447.64.text: I mean, it's more likely to be Piers Morgan,

1451.16.text: but somewhere at the back of my mind,

1453.16.text: I think, unlikely as it may sound...

1457.52.text:
- We'll go for that. 
- Are you sure?

1459.36.text: Your instinct's been good up till now, yeah.

1461.40.text: We'll go with Beverly's instinct, Jeremy -

1463.52.text: it's been sound up until now -

1465.12.text: and we'll go with James Corden.

1467.68.text: James Corden is your answer, and it's correct. Well done.

1471.48.text: He went over to the States to ply his trade.

1476.80.text: the Red Bull Formula One boss Christian Horner in 2015?

1485.84.text:
- Geri Halliwell? 
- Yes, it's Geri Halliwell. 
- Geri Halliwell, yeah?

1491.24.text: And CJ is nodding, so you must be right.

1493.76.text: Geri Halliwell is the right answer.

1499.20.text: You must get this one right

1500.52.text: because you slipped up on your first question.

1502.84.text: So, take your time here, ladies.

1504.64.text: In Greek mythology, the god Zeus appeared to Danae

1514.76.text: Do you think that's where diamond's from? Diamante...

1523.04.text:
- Do you think? 
- Yeah, there could be a link between that.

1529.40.text:
- WHISPERS: 
- But I think it's gold.

1533.56.text: Shall we? Are you happy with that?

1535.64.text: My instinct says gold, but let's go with diamonds.

1540.04.text: No. What does your instinct say?

1544.08.text: because, after all, you have to mine for diamonds.

1552.60.text: Who he appeared to, so it's not Zeus that...

1556.56.text: It's not Zeus that would be linked to the diamonds -

1559.84.text: it would be the other person.

1561.76.text:
- The other's Danae? 
- Yeah, I would go for gold or silver.

1566.20.text: OK, we'll go with gold. That was your first instinct.

1569.44.text:
- Sorry if I'm wrong. 
- No, it's all right.

1571.16.text:
- We'll go with gold, Jeremy. 
- So, your answer is gold? 
- Mm-hm.

1575.40.text: Shall we check with the Eggheads? Eggheads?

1577.44.text:
- Gold. 
- Yeah, you got it right.

1578.84.text:
- Well done. 
- Well done to you.

1580.76.text:
- I'm so pleased. Well done. 
- Thank you, Jeremy.

1584.68.text: OK, so you've got two out of three there.

1586.68.text: You just have to hope, fingers crossed, everything crossed now.

1591.20.text:
- That's true. 
- Have to hope they get this one wrong.

1607.28.text:
- Happy with 11? 
- Want to run us through them all, Kevin?

1610.88.text: You'll be asked to in a minute. But you're going with 11?

1614.60.text: OK, Kevin is sure that it's 11, Jeremy.

1620.20.text: 11? I thought you might go with five.

1622.52.text:
- Do you know them all? 
- I've seen the list.

1625.40.text: You know, it's going to have everything from...

1627.44.text: Obviously English is in there, Xhosa, Zulu, various other...

1631.12.text:
- Afrikaans. 
- Afrikaans should be there, you're right, yeah.

1634.76.text: Well, if you've got it wrong,

1637.08.text: we play on and there's £13,000 on the table,

1639.28.text: but you have got it right,

1640.84.text:
- so we say congratulations, Eggheads. 
- Well done, Kevin.

1643.24.text: 11 is the answer, and you have won.

1650.64.text: I thought they would struggle with that.

1652.92.text: So did I! I hoped, I hoped they would.

1655.16.text: I just thought there was going to be a battle over five and 11 there.

1658.72.text: No, I thought with all the tribal languages that...

1663.12.text:
- Well, thank you for playing. 
- Thanks you. 
- Enjoyed it.

1665.44.text:
- Knotty Knitters, we all want to start knitting now, don't we? 
- Yeah.

1668.76.text: Speak for yourself, I already do.

1670.84.text: Of course you do. Of course you do. What have you knitted recently?

1673.64.text: I'm all right as long as it hasn't got sleeves in it,

1675.96.text: at which point it starts getting complicated.

1680.40.text: The Eggheads have done what comes naturally to them.

1684.24.text: becoming a little bit impressive now.

1686.12.text: It does mean you won't be going home with the £13,000,

1690.40.text: Eggheads, congratulations. Who will beat you?

1693.80.text: Join us next time to see if a new team of Challengers

1696.00.text: have the brains to defeat the Eggheads.

1698.08.text: £14,000 is what they'll be playing for.
